Beta-D-glucan is not absorbed whole; instead, enterocytes take up its breakdown products through active transport mechanisms. Beta-D-glucans are thought to be able to cross the basolateral membrane once they are inside the enterocyte and enter the bloodstream, where they can interact with different immune system cells.

Up to 80% of oat beta-D-glucan has been reported to be bioavailable in people. Within 24 hours, the majority (roughly 50%) of a dose of beta-D-glucan taken orally is eliminated in the feces.
